seo.metaTitle: NWA Daily - A daily newsletter about all things Northwest Arkansas
seo.metaDescription: NWA Daily is a daily email newsletter that keeps readers up to date on the latest Northwest Arkansas news or NWA news in events, restaurants, business,  the community, politics, art, entertainment, culture, and sports in Northwest Arkansas including news about Bentonville, Rogers, Springdale, and Fayetteville

node.description:
The brick-lined streets of downtown Rogers are ready for your feet this Thursday, Sept. 9 for the Art on the Bricks Art Walk.

  • Arkansas art: You can meet local artists, visit pop-up galleries and art exhibits, and pop in to local restaurants and breweries while you shop around town from 4:30-7:30p. There will be live music in various locations intermingled with the artists and antiques stores. 
  • Get around: The Ozark Regional Transit will be providing free shuttles around town, stopping at each location 2 times per hour. 

Click HERE for a map of participating locations, parking and shuttle stops.
node.name: Art on the Bricks

node.description: Movie night: Come hang at Coler mountain on the homestead tonight for an outdoor movie!
node.name: Coler Bike-In Movie

node.description: Play ball: Razorback baseball is back with the first scrimmage of the season tonight at 6p.
node.name: Fall Classic

node.description: Music on the tracks: Pick a day this weekend to listen to great artists performing live at the Railyard.
node.name: Railyard Live

node.description: Life's like a movie: Arkansas Public Theatre is showing Avenue Q all weekend. Would recommend.
node.name: Avenue Q

node.description: Explore: Brain to Brain Paper Plane is still in Downtown Springdale. Make it a trip, see it if you haven't already.
node.name: Famous Hardware

node.description:
This Saturday you can ride down the Razorback Greenway and make pit stops for tacos with the Tour de Tacos event. 

  • For young mothers: This will be the 2nd annual Tour de Tacos put on by the Compassion House. All funding will go toward providing pregnant and parenting teens a place to live along with an empowering support system. The Compassion House works to equip young mothers to be the best parents they can be. 
  • Taco tour: There is a 7 mile, 30 mile and 62 mile ride along the Greenway. The routes begin and end at Lewis and Clark in Rogers. Strava has a map of the tour. Day of event registration is $75. 

For more details, click HERE.
node.name: Tour de Tacos

node.description: Jammin': Hit up Prairie Street in Fayetteville for a Concert Against Cancer this Saturday.
node.name: Concert Against Cancer

node.description: Horns down: The Longhorns are coming to town to rekindle an old rivalry in a highly anticipated matchup.
node.name: Arkansas vs. UT

node.description: Party like we used to: Celebrate our first responders with face painting, a dunk tank, dancing and more with Moonbroch in Rogers.
node.name: Moonbroch

node.description:
Show up to The Barn at the Springs on Sept. 17 for a good time and a good cause! 

  • Get together: Shared Beginnings is putting on a party on Sept. 17 from 6-10p to raise money for mothers and expectant mothers considering adoption. There will be carnival style games, inflatables and an array of NWA’s finest food vendors. 
  • Support: Your ticket includes a Shared Beginnings signature cocktail, and you can purchase an add-on for 3 drinks if you so please. The proceeds of the evening will go toward therapy and support for those who need it. 

For more information and tickets, click HERE.
node.name: Arkansas Local

node.description: Deepwood Mac is a tribute band to Fleetwood Mac performing at Prairie Street Live. Tickets are $15.
node.name: Deepwood Mac

node.description:
Crystal Bridges is hosting an array of wonderful ways get outside and learn this weekend:

Art by the Glass: Floral Cookie Decorating

Fim Screening: Fantastic Fungi

Discover the Grounds: Native Herbs

Discover the Grounds Workshop: Herbal Tea Blends

Garden Party
node.name: Nature Weekend

node.description: The pop-up art market will be Friday and Saturday specifically highlighting visual arts and featuring local artists who represent a range of styles and mediums.
node.name: Pop-Up Art Market
node.location: Brick & Mortar 120 W. Walnut Street Rogers, AR 72756

node.description: Tickets: $15
node.name: Deepwood Mac at Prairie Street Live

node.description: Free-$20
node.name: The Mixtapes at the Butterfield Stage

node.description: The city of Fayetteville is hosting a clean up day as opportunity for us to give back to our beautiful home.
node.name: Pick Up Where You Play

node.description:
Whether you’re good at pickleball or tennis or not, it doesn’t really matter. You can help raise money for the NWA Women’s Shelter by registering to play Sept. 18. 

  • Sports for charity: The NWA Challenge for Hope is in its 30th year of raising money for charity. This year’s fundraisers are a golf tournament, which took place on Monday, and a pickleball and tennis tournament on Sept. 18 at the Pinnacle Country Club. 
  • Pro clinic: Get together with a team and attend a clinic with the pros on Sept. 17 to prepare you for the big day. Registration will include the clinic on the 17th, merchandise, lunch & dinner on the 18th, and a dance party to end the event. 

Click HERE for details.
node.name: NWA Challenge for Hope

node.description:
Free (reserved ticket required for seating)

Table seating $20 (seats up to 4 people)
node.name: Eureka Strings at the Railyard

node.description: The Natural State Beer Co. is kicking off to the Oktoberfest season with a fundraiser event full of local brews, games, food and so much more.
node.name: NSB Oktoberfest

node.description: This is the 5th annual festival full of family friendly cultural music and dancing.
node.name: International Music and Dance Festival
node.organization: The Botanical Garden of the Ozarks

node.description: No Tears Suite was originally performed at Central High School Historical Site for the 60th anniversary of the Little Rock Nine. This event will be performed by the original writers joined by a band of professional jazz musicians.
node.name: No Tears Suite

node.description:
If you see smoke in the air on Saturday, Sept. 25, it’s most likely folks barbecuing in Rogers. 

  • The 6th annual Frisco Inferno Barbecue Competition & Tasting is happening in Downtown Rogers, and anyone can enter a team and bring their smoker to participate. There is an entry fee, but the winners get cash prizes. 
  • Kingsford is sponsoring the event, bringing live music and donations to educate attendees about the Black history of pit barbecue. 

Learn more and sign up HERE.
node.name: Frisco Inferno

node.description: Tickets: Adults $14, Kids $9. Get tickets at rodeooftheozarks.org or the Ticket Office at Parsons Stadium.
node.name: Demolition Derby

node.description: 27 local vendors are gathering to sell hand-made items!
node.name: 5th Street Makers Market

node.description:
There’s a live performance coming back to the exterior wall of The Momentary Tower. And it’s so cool, it’s members only. 

  • Reimagined: BANDALOOP is choreography, climbing and dancing all on a vertical stage — in this case, The Tower facade. Before BANDALOOP there will be a screening of an award winning short film, followed by a performance by FLOOD. Show up to bend your perspective on Sept. 28.
  • Perks: You can become a Momentary member for only $75/yr or $6.50/mo. Sign up today to have access to member exclusive events like this one. 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: BANDALOOP

node.description:
Alright Robin Hoods and Katniss Everdeens, it’s your time to shine at the new archery range in Bentonville. 

  • Bows and arrows: The Quiver Archery Range in Osage Park is set to open Wed, Sept. 29. There will be opportunity to do archery by the hour, participate in individual programs, or be a member with a starting cost of $100/yr .
  • Pro or no pro: Whether you just want the basics, or you dream of being a certified archer, The Quiver has a program for you. It will be open 11a-5p and is located at 1701 SE F St. in Bentonville.

Check out programs and memberships HERE.
node.name: Quiver Archery Range Opening

node.description: GRAMMY Award winning artist Grace Potter will be on the Momentary Green and admission is free, though registration is required.
node.name: Grace Potter

node.description: Bikers are starting at the Square in Bentonville and finishing at Walker Park in Fayetteville. The Halfway Halt is back at Turnbow Park in Springdale as a midway point on the 30 mile journey.
node.name: Square 2 Square

node.description: Pottery on the Patio is 5-8pm the first four Saturdays of October at Nadine Baum Studios on Spring Street. There will be food, music, free mini lessons on the pottery wheel, space for sidewalk murals, bike decorating, button making, and watercolor painting.
node.name: Pottery on the Patio

node.description:
Modern artists and their art exhibits are constantly expanding the definition of what art is and how it can be displayed. The Momentary in Bentonville is in the lineup for the first U.S. showings of a Golden Lion Award winning installation of art. 

  • The space between: Sun & Sea is an indoor beach opera by an all-female creative team who focus on how “theater, music, and the visual arts intertwine.” 
  • Get in on it: The Momentary will be transforming the interior Tower space, importing 25 tons of sand and inviting 13 vocalists to put on the 60 minute show Oct 6-9. Tickets are available to museum members today and nonmembers starting Monday. 

Learn more and get Tickets HERE.
node.name: Sun & Sea at the Momentary

node.description: The Art Walk evenings will be filled with entertainment, food, drinks, and music to accompany the creative spaces on display.
node.name: Art Walk

node.description:
Calling ALL lovers of art, movement, exercise, nature, dance, and coffee!

Join Ozark Ballet Theater and Guest Teacher Karen Castleman in welcoming the beautiful Autumn weather! Friday Oct. 8th at 11 AM, take a lovely stroll at the Coler Preserve, find a hidden getaway featuring an Airship Coffee location and a gorgeous natural setting to experience a simple, FREE introduction to modern dance. This event is open to EVERYONE. NO experience required.

Enjoy low-impact breathing and dance exercises outdoors and then grab a tea or coffee and relax on the gorgeous Airship porch. As a bonus - all attendees will receive 15% off their Airship order!

Bring shoes you're comfortable in or go barefoot if you'd prefer! attendees are welcome to bring blankets and chairs - this is a zero-pressure session. Relax, have fun, sit down and follow with your arms if you'd like, just get moving with us on a Friday morning! We will gather at 11 and get started by 11:15

Ozark Ballet Theater is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit with a mission to improve access to professional quality dance training throughout Northwest Arkansas. While this event is offered for free to the public, we are suggesting a donation of $8 to cover our event expenses.

Follow us on Facebook and Instagram and Subscribe to our mailing list at www.obt.dance to keep up with our diverse free program offerings!

Please pre-register online at www.obt.dance/Modern

Donate To OBT! Visit www.Givebutter.com/OBT
node.name: Dance in the Grass

node.description: Osage Park is celebrating this unique space by bringing together the community and amazing organizations for this one-day event. The park will be filled with different opportunities to learn, play, and eat.
node.name: A Day at Osage Park

node.description: Buddy Pegs is hosting a race series for kids ages 2-12. It will be 4 different weekends: Oct 9, Oct 30, Nov. 13, Dec 11.
node.name: Pedal Kids Race Series

node.name: Pottery on the Patio

node.description:
The UCI Cyclo-cross World Cup will appear in Fayetteville twice over the season’s duration, first a month from today on Oct. 13, and second for the World Championships in January next year. 

  • History in the making: Both races will be at Centennial Park in Fayetteville, making Oct. 13 a first-take for what to expect at the biggest event for Cyclo-cross and the finale of it all.
  • International event: The 2021-2022 UCI Cyclo-cross World Cup will visit 5 countries over its course, and athletes from over 20 countries will be represented. 

Click HERE for more.
node.name: UCI Cyclo-cross World Cup

node.description: Big bonfires and small bonfires will be lit Oct 15 from 6-9p to gather around and have Ozarktober fun.
node.name: Fall Bonfire

node.description: Pottery on the Patio is 5-8pm the first four Saturdays of October at Nadine Baum Studios on Spring Street. There will be food, music, free mini lessons on the pottery wheel, space for sidewalk murals, bike decorating, button making, and watercolor painting.

node.description:
Buddy Pegs is hosting a race series for kids ages 2-12. Oct 30 is the second of four weekends, and is the race day for spookiness, so get ready.

The next races will be on Nov 13 and Dec 11.
node.name: Pedal Kids Race Series

node.description: Buddy Pegs is hosting a race series for kids 2-12. This is the 3rd weekend of 4. The last races will be on Dec 11.
node.name: Pedal Kids Race Series

node.description: The Art Walk evenings will be filled with entertainment, food, drinks, and music to accompany the creative spaces on display.
node.name: Art Walk

node.description: Buddy Pegs is hosting a bicycle race series for kids 2-12, and Dec 11 is the last day of the races.
node.name: Pedal Kids Race Series

node.description:
The Heartland Summit kicks off tomorrow with two community events open to the public, while others are invitation-only. 

  • Events: On May 11, there will be a screening of the HBO documentary “Our Towns,” and a discussion afterward, at The Momentary. The event is free with advanced registration. The following day, May 12, two-time Grammy award-winning string band Old Crow Medicine will perform for the public as part of the Momentary’s Live on the Green Concert Series. Tickets start at $20.
  • Problem-solving: The convening at the Heartland Summit in Bentonville is all about having a conversation with today’s leading thinkers, innovators, policymakers, and investors to create powerful networks that will forge paths of progress and turn great ideas into action. 

Learn more about Heartland Summit HERE.
node.name: Heartland Summit

node.description:
The 2021/22 Broadway season at the Walton Arts Center is coming to a close, but not without a grand finale. 

  • Showings: Fiddler on the Roof begins tonight as the last show of the season, and it will run through Sunday, May 15. The best seating availability is on Thursday, May 12 at 1:30p, though tickets for all shows are still available.
  • Shows old and new: The team behind South Pacific, The King and I, and Oslo are bringing a “fresh and authentic vision” to a “gorgeous new production” of Fiddler on the Roof this season. The 2022/23 P&G Broadway Series will begin August 9 with My Fair Lady. 

Listen to cast member Not Luz Barenblat talk about the Fiddler on the Roof tour HERE.
node.name: Fiddler on the Roof

node.description:
Music festivals are happening left and right, and we couldn’t be more excited! The Arkansas Brewgrass Fest will be back for its 5th year on May 15, and it promises a day of good music, good drinks, and good times on the Fayetteville Town Square. 

  • Line-up: A new band from Eureka Springs called Front Porch will be kicking off the festival, then Fayetteville darling Jess Harp will perform before the headliner, Rachel Ammons and her No Man Band. 
  • More than music: There will be brews from local brewery Fossil Cove, CBD cocktails from Buffalo Brothers, free bingo, kids' activities, local arts & craft vendors, and food trucks to enjoy. Admission is $10 and everyone 17 years old and younger will get in free. 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Arkansas Brewgrass Fest

node.description:
It’s warming up and summer weekends are just around the corner. You might want to save your Saturday evenings for live outdoor concerts at Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art. 

  • Evening festivities: The Forest Concert Series is returning this summer to merge national and local musicians in the Cristal Bridges North Forest. The performances will be outdoors surrounded by art and nature, including a food truck, cash bar, and art-making activities.
  • Under the trees: There are eight concerts scheduled throughout the summer, and they are $12 to attend (18 and under are free). The first concert is scheduled for May 28. Be sure to bring your lawn chair or blanket to enjoy live music under the trees. 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Forest Concert Series
node.location: Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art
node.organization: Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art

node.description:
Barnett's Dairyette, a classic burger, shake, and ice cream joint in Siloam Springs, is celebrating its 65th anniversary this year, and they're inviting everyone to the party on June 3rd.

  • A staple: Barnett's was opened in 1957 and became an integral part of summer fun in Siloam providing soft serve, shakes, and classic burgers. Siloam entrepreneur, Jacob Frese, took Barnett's over in 2017 and has been continuing the restaurant's rich history.
  • Celebrate good times: 65 years makes Barnett's one of the oldest restaurants in NWA still in operation, and that's cause for celebration! The team at Barnett's has put a great day together for anyone and everyone that wants to join in on the fun.

Head on over to Barnett's on June 3rd to celebrate with them!
node.name: Barnett's 65th Anniversary Celebration

node.description:
Get ready for a full day of fun at CACHE Studios on June 4 with a collab between CACHE and Trike Theatre. On top of a fun itinerary, there's no reservation or registration required and the event is free for everyone.

  • More than a show: In addition to the main show, there will be art making activities, sensory play stations, and more.
  • Showtime: At 10am and 12pm there will be dance performances, and then at 1pm Trike Theatre's Mariposa/Butterfly (the main event) will begin.

Check out the itinerary for this fun event here.
node.name: CACHE and Trike Theatre Team Up to Host Family Day

node.description:
It was a bummer to have the Fayetteville OZ Kids(TM) Fat Tire Crit event canceled due to weather, but the show will go on! We’re pumped for the next event in Springdale coming up next week! 

  • Kid racers: The OZ Kids Crit in Springdale will take place on June 8. There are seven categories for different age groups from 2-11 years old, and the age of the riders will determine the number of laps in each race.
  • To the finish: Each race is $20, and the fun is priceless. And as always, costumes are encouraged for all riders and volunteers, and the best costume will get a prize! 

Learn more and register for a Springdale race HERE, and get ready to have a blast!
node.name: OZ Fat Tire Kids Crit Ready For Springdale

node.description:
You may want to start clearing your calendar for Thursday evenings because the Fayetteville's Gulley Park Concert Series starts tomorrow.

  • Tunes in the air: The 26th annual Gulley Park Summer Concert Series kicks off tomorrow, June 9th, with concerts every Thursday evening until July 14th. Shows start at 7p around the Gulley Park Gazebo, and there will be a local food truck rally for those attending the concerts.
node.name: Blue Water Highway - Gully Park Concert Series

node.description:
The Bentonville Bike Fest is almost upon us. Scheduled for this weekend, June 17-19, it’s shaping up to be bigger and better than ever before. 

  • Day in, day out: Bike Fest will consist of a variety of races, workshops, and UCI-sanctioned events. The schedule is action-packed, and there is something for every style and level of rider. 
  • Ride together: From group rides to a movie under the stars to a scavenger hunt on bikes to a Guinness World Record attempt, this year's event has it all and is a great way to get plugged into the NWA cycling scene.

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Bentonville Bike Fest

node.description:
Summer at Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art never disappoints with 120 acres in full bloom and new exhibitions and events ready to inspire. 

  • Go see: This year, Crystal Bridges is bursting with every rendition of art for you to experience, from an outdoor architecture exhibition to festivities of celebration and concerts to an original print of a US document arriving at the galleries.
  • Coming up: Today begins a weekend dedicated to The Dirty South, an exhibition celebrating Black culture. In addition to a lineup of events through June 17, there will be free admission to The Dirty South June 18-19.

Check out the Crystal Bridges summer guide HERE.
node.name: The Dirty South
node.location: Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art - Bentonville, AR
node.organization: Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art

node.description:
A Fayetteville Roots event is coming up this weekend called Fayetteville Roots on the Avenue. 

  • Music in the street: Fayetteville Roots on the Avenue is an outdoor street concert series — three nights, nine performing artists on a stage on East Avenue in Downtown Fayetteville, just outside the Roots HQ.
  • Come on in: There will be tables for four and two, standing cocktail tables, and designated standing areas, all on a first-come, first-serve basis throughout the outdoor venue. Tickets are all general admission and start at $50, and Pizza and other snacks will be available to purchase along with drinks. 

Click HERE for more details.
node.name: Fayetteville Roots on the Avenue

node.description:
Juneteenth is approaching, and there are a few big ways to celebrate coming up in Northwest Arkansas.

  • Connections: Juneteenth is now a federal holiday commemorating the day all Americans became free. As a part of the community’s celebrations this weekend and to bring awareness, education, and exposure, the Second Annual Arkansas Black Film Showcase will be at Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art today at 6p. 
  • For all to celebrate: On Sunday, June 19, is the 2022 Freedom Festival, a free Juneteenth celebration that will be held at Shiloh Square in downtown Springdale from 1-9p. The event will feature music by loved artists, free food, games, exhibits, giveaways, a wellness fair, and more. 

Click HERE for more information.
node.name: 2022 Freedom Festival

node.description:
You may want to start clearing your calendar for Thursday evenings because the Fayetteville's Gulley Park Concert Series starts tomorrow.

  • Tunes in the air: The 26th annual Gulley Park Summer Concert Series kicks off tomorrow, June 9th, with concerts every Thursday evening until July 14th. Shows start at 7p around the Gulley Park Gazebo, and there will be a local food truck rally for those attending the concerts.
node.name: King Cabbage Brass - Gully Park Concert Series

node.description:
Tis the season for summer series! In addition to starting a summer series tomorrow, Johnson is hosting its grand opening of Johnson Square.

  • The event: The Square is right next door to Hail Fellow Well Met at 5467 Hackett St., and live music by Nathan Perry and Smokey and the Mirror will start at 6p. The party will officially run until 8p, and there will be food and drinks too, so bring your friends!
  • The lineup: The summer series will continue on June 24 with a movie night, July 22 with Oh Jeremiah, August 26 with a movie night, and September 8 with The Riverside.

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Movie Night - Johnson Square Summer Series

node.description:
The Walton Arts Center (WAC) recently wrapped up the P&G Broadway Series with Fiddler on the Roof, but fans have one more chance to see a Broadway show this season.

  • Exclusive: "A Chorus Line" will be at the WAC for a four-show run June 24-26 before launching an Asian tour. The performances in Northwest Arkansas are the only opportunities to see this new tour in the United States.
  • Iconic: "A Chorus Line" is the musical for "everyone who's ever had a dream and put it on the line." The show first debuted in 1975, and the iconic score features classics such as "What I Did for Love," "One," "I Hope I Get It," and more. 

For more tickets and info, click HERE.
node.name: A Chorus Line - Walton Arts Center

node.description:
It’s never dull at the Momentary, especially in the summertime with new exhibits and concerts on the horizon.

  • A happenin' place: In addition to new interactive art exhibitions spanning the Momentary grounds, you can expect to see new sculptures, screenings, and new sound. The Live on the Green series is lined up for the rest of the year with great musical talent.
  • Listen & learn: The two Live on the Green concerts this summer are Kraftwerk 3-D on June 26 and Run the Jewels & Big Boi on July 16. The War on Drugs is coming in September, and Lyle Lovett & John Hiatt in October.

Read more about the Momentary's summer plans HERE.
node.name: Kraftwerk 3-D - Live on the Green

node.description:
The Fayetteville Public Library is kicking off its Mountain Street Stage concert series next Sunday, June 5. 

  • The series: Adam Ostrar is a singer-songwriter based out of Austin, TX. Joined by his trusty Gretch Country Gentleman guitar, Adam sings his way through anxiety and despair brought on by our current state of affairs. The subsequent events will be July 3, 10, and 24. 
  • Listen: The Library will cap the event at 200 persons for the health and safety of the performers and the music-loving community. You will be able to live stream the concert on Facebook Live and watch it after the performance, too! 

For more information about the June 26 event, click HERE.
node.name: Adam Ostrar - Mountain Street Stage

node.description:
Art Ventures in Fayetteville is presenting a new exhibit called Threads of Identity beginning this Wednesday, June 29. 

  • Seeing ourselves: Art Ventures NWA is a non-profit charitable and educational organization dedicated to providing access to Art for Everyone. Threads of Identity will feature artists who explore artistic expression and cultural identity through the subjects of fashion and style.
  • Community collaboration: The artworks will demonstrate the intertwining of different mediums such as ceramics, textile artwork, traditional painting, clothing design, and more. The exhibition will be on display from June 29-August 28 at the Art Ventures NWA gallery located at 20 S Hill Ave, and an opening public reception will be held during Fayetteville's First Thursday event.

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Art Ventures Presents New Art Exhibition

node.description:
You may want to start clearing your calendar for Thursday evenings because the Fayetteville's Gulley Park Concert Series starts tomorrow.

  • Tunes in the air: The 26th annual Gulley Park Summer Concert Series kicks off tomorrow, June 9th, with concerts every Thursday evening until July 14th. Shows start at 7p around the Gulley Park Gazebo, and there will be a local food truck rally for those attending the concerts.
node.name: Funk Factory - Gully Park Concert Series

node.description:
Bentonville’s First Friday is this coming Friday, July 1, and the theme is American Spirit! 

  • Prepare for fun: First Friday kicks off at 11a, and a full day of games, activities, music, and food is prepared for this monthly block party. In addition to rockin’ live bands, there will be trampoline shows on the MainStage that include Olympic-type routines!
  • To expect: Walmart is celebrating its 60th anniversary and has plans to show up in a big way this Friday. The beer garden will be back at the garden on “the field” at the corner of Central and SE A St, and Better Homes and Gardens Journey is hosting a Good Ol’ Fashion Watermelon Eating Contest. Big prizes for raffle winners are on the table, too. 

Click HERE for more details.
node.name: Bentonville First Friday

node.description:
The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art exhibition We the People: The Radical Notion of Democracy opens this weekend. 

  • Special in NWA: We the People: The Radical Notion of Democracy is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for guests to see one of the original prints of the U.S. constitution. Members are invited for the first look on Thursday and Friday, and the general public will have access to the exhibition on Saturday, July 2.
  • Conversation: In addition to the U.S. Constitution, several new acquisitions will be present for viewings, such as original prints of the Declaration of Independence, the proposed Bill of Rights, and the Articles of Confederation. The documents will be displayed alongside works of art that provide diverse American perspectives on the nations founding principles.

Click HERE for more information.
node.name: Latest Crystal Bridges Exhibition To Open This Weekend
node.organization: Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art

node.description:
The Fayetteville Public Library is kicking off its Mountain Street Stage concert series next Sunday, June 5. 

  • The series: Jude Brothers uses a variety of stringed instruments (banjo, guitar, harp) and her dynamic singing to combine elements of chamber and folk music into a live performance that is both idiosyncratic and cathartic. The subsequent events will be July 10, and 24. 
  • Listen: The Library will cap the event at 200 persons for the health and safety of the performers and the music-loving community. You will be able to live stream the concert on Facebook Live and watch it after the performance, too! 

For more information about the June 26 event, click HERE.
node.name: Jude Brothers - Mountain Street Stage

node.description:
Independence Day is almost here, and there are plenty of places to celebrate in Northwest Arkansas. 

  • Celebrate in NWA: Arvest Ballpark and the Walmart AMP are both hosting firework shows on July 4th, paired with a baseball game or a concert, depending on where you are. Orchards Park in Bentonville will be hosting its Evening at Orchards Park on the 4th as well with food trucks and live music. 
  • More events and info: Fayetteville has released safety reminders and city firework rules and included info about the two city-sponsored events this weekend. Here is a working list of firework events around NWA and beyond this weekend compiled by 4029 News.

Wherever you celebrate this weekend, remember to be safe! Tag us on social media with your photos — we’d love to share!
node.name: Fourth of July Fireworks Celebrations

node.description:
You may want to start clearing your calendar for Thursday evenings because the Fayetteville's Gulley Park Concert Series starts tomorrow.

  • Tunes in the air: The 26th annual Gulley Park Summer Concert Series kicks off tomorrow, June 9th, with concerts every Thursday evening until July 14th. Shows start at 7p around the Gulley Park Gazebo, and there will be a local food truck rally for those attending the concerts.
node.name: Pert Near Sandstone - Gully Park Concert Series

node.description:
The Fayetteville Public Library is kicking off its Mountain Street Stage concert series next Sunday, June 5. 

  • The series: Daniel Bennett is an accomplished jazz musician who plays the saxophone, flute, and clarinet. The subsequent events will be July 24. 
  • Listen: The Library will cap the event at 200 persons for the health and safety of the performers and the music-loving community. You will be able to live stream the concert on Facebook Live and watch it after the performance, too! 

For more information about the June 26 event, click HERE.
node.name: Daniel Bennett Group - Mountain Street Stage

node.description:
You may want to start clearing your calendar for Thursday evenings because the Fayetteville's Gulley Park Concert Series starts tomorrow.

  • Tunes in the air: The 26th annual Gulley Park Summer Concert Series kicks off tomorrow, June 9th, with concerts every Thursday evening until July 14th. Shows start at 7p around the Gulley Park Gazebo, and there will be a local food truck rally for those attending the concerts.
node.name: Brennen Leigh - Gully Park Concert Series

node.description:
The Scott Family Amazeum is celebrating its 7th birthday on Friday (July 15) all day long, and you’re invited! 

  • A wool party: The birthday theme is based on the traditional seventh-anniversary gift of wool, so guests can experience a variety of pop-up activities like felting, finger knitting, and painting with yarn. And for extra holly fun, the Amazeum will host the Barn Yard Buddies Petting Zoo and demonstrations from the NWA Weavers Guild. 
  • For everyone: The Amazeum is part children’s museum, part science center, and part maker space, providing experiences designed for adults as well as children and families. All the birthday activities on Friday will be included with general admission to the museum. 

Learn more HERE!
node.name: Amazeum To Host Its 7th Birthday Party

node.description:
The Arkansas Enduro Series is coming to Centennial Park in Fayetteville this weekend, and online registration closes today at 8p. 

  • The series: Enduro is a competition, party, spectating event, and family fun with music, food, and beer! The racing combines multiple aspects of mountain bike disciplines and required terrain adaptability. Fayetteville’s event is the third of five events in the series. 
  • The races: Racers in the series earn points during races, and the Series Overall Points will be decided by the best 3 out of five races in each category. There will be “Flavor of Enduro” races on Friday for no series points for people who want a taste, and the series races for points and all skill levels will be on Saturday.

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Arkansas Enduro Series Comes To Fayetteville This Weekend

node.description:
Go ahead and mark your calendars for July 16 for one of Northwest Arkansas's most anticipated mid-summer events - the Firefly Fling Festival.

  • Anticipation: Thousands of families from across the area come to the Botanical Garden of the Ozarks and don the costumes of their favorite fairy or woodland-themed characters each year as they attend the Firefly Fling Festival.
  • Fun and games: Before the sun goes down, kids will be able to enjoy fairy house building, nature stations, crafts, and more. After dark, the whole family can enjoy live music on the Great Lawn and some great food from the food trucks in attendance.

Learn more about the event or go ahead and pick up your tickets here.
node.name: Firefly Fling Festival
node.location: Botanical Garden of the Ozarks, Fayetteville, AR

node.description:
It’s never dull at the Momentary, especially in the summertime with new exhibits and concerts on the horizon.

  • A happenin' place: In addition to new interactive art exhibitions spanning the Momentary grounds, you can expect to see new sculptures, screenings, and new sound. The Live on the Green series is lined up for the rest of the year with great musical talent.
  • Listen & learn: The two Live on the Green concerts this summer are Kraftwerk 3-D on June 26 and Run the Jewels & Big Boi on July 16. The War on Drugs is coming in September, and Lyle Lovett & John Hiatt in October.

Read more about the Momentary's summer plans HERE.
node.name: Run the Jewels & Big Boi - Live on the Green

node.description:
Tis the season for summer series! In addition to starting a summer series tomorrow, Johnson is hosting its grand opening of Johnson Square.

  • The event: The Square is right next door to Hail Fellow Well Met at 5467 Hackett St., and live music by Nathan Perry and Smokey and the Mirror will start at 6p. The party will officially run until 8p, and there will be food and drinks too, so bring your friends!
  • The lineup: The summer series will continue on June 24 with a movie night, July 22 with Oh Jeremiah, August 26 with a movie night, and September 8 with The Riverside.

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Oh Jeremiah - Johnson Square Summer Series

node.description:
The Momentary has more music in store for you this summer and fall, ranging from free concerts to multi-day events. 

  • Grab a blanket: Free concerts on the green will be on select Fridays starting this Friday, July 22, with the Manhattan Chamber Players String Sextet at 8p. Carm will perform on August 12 and Willi Carlisle on August 26. Stay tuned for more singer-songwriters, bands, and special guests. 
  • Teaser: Some ticketed performances and events include two-time Grammy-nominated indie pop artist Japanese Breakfast, the Tigran Hamasyan Trio, The War on Drugs kicking off FORMAT Festival, and a new festival experience - Momentous - with the full lineup of artists still to be announced. 

See the live music show lineup HERE.
node.name: Manhattan Chamber Players String Sextet - Concerts on the Green

node.description:
The Fayetteville Public Library is kicking off its Mountain Street Stage concert series next Sunday, June 5. 

  • The series: Western Swing Rules Band are Arkansas' only western swing band currently nominated for Western Swing Group of the Year by the Academy of Western Artists. The subsequent events will be July 24. 
  • Listen: The Library will cap the event at 200 persons for the health and safety of the performers and the music-loving community. You will be able to live stream the concert on Facebook Live and watch it after the performance, too! 

For more information about the June 26 event, click HERE.
node.name: Western Swing Rules Band - Mountain Street Stage

node.description:
The Arts One Presents summer musical performances begin tomorrow at the Pat Ellison Performing Arts Center in the Don Tyson School of Innovation.

  • The show: This year’s summer musical is The Hunchback of Notre Dame, based on the 1831 novel by Victor Hugo with songs from the 1996 Walt Disney Animation Studios. Performance dates are Thursday, July 21, through Sunday, July 24, and Thursday, July 28 through Sunday, July 31. Tickets are on sale now and can be purchased online.
  • The biz: Arts One Presents, based in Springdale, empowers artists, enriches businesses, and engages community through accessible and inclusive visual and performing arts experiences. Through collaborations with artists and businesses in the Northwest Arkansas area, Arts One Presents offers public art experiences, community theater, and programming for all. 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Arts One Presents Summer Musical Performances
node.location: Don Tyson School of Innovation - Springdale, AR

node.description:
The Tontitown Grape Festival is coming up in August for its 123rd year!

  • Festivities: The festival is free to attend and will take place August 2-6. Nightly entertainment, including grape stomping, arts and crafts, bingo, and more, will be free for all who attend. Admission to carnival rides will cost $25 on Tuesday-Thursday and $30 on Friday and Saturday. 
  • Dinner tradition: In addition to fun activities, the festival is known for its spaghetti dinners made from scratch by volunteers. According to the website, dinner comes with rolls and fried chicken and costs $12 per adult and $6 per child. 

Click HERE for more details.
node.name: Tontitown Grape Festival

node.description:
First Thursday is back this week at the Fayetteville Downtown Square, and August’s theme is “Dog Daze” presented by Best Friends Animal Society. 

  • Best in Show: If you think your furry friend has what it takes to win over the judges, register them for the Dog Daze Pageant. Not a pageant pup? No worries. Everyone’s invited to join the pack after the show for Pups on Parade.
  • The Local Lineup: As usual, the event will celebrate Fayetteville's local arts culture, music, food, and beer. There will be a stellar lineup of food trucks present, and performances by 90’s cover band Feats of Strength and hip-hop artist Jasper Logan. 

See more event details HERE.
node.name: Fayetteville First Thursday

node.description:
Ever wondered if you have what it takes to begin a startup company? Startup Junkie and The Venture Center want to help you take your first step during Techstars Startup Weekend NWA. 

  • Teamwork: Over the weekend of August 26-28, participants will be surrounded by like-minded entrepreneurs and learn from experienced mentors, investors, co-founders, and sponsors to gain insights on starting a business. 
  • Makes the dream work: Teams will form around chosen ideas in the focus areas of Outdoor Recreation, Web3, and General to create a working prototype, demo, and pitch a presentation for a chance to win $5,000. 

Learn more and register HERE.
node.name: Techstars Startup Weekend NWA

node.description:
This month’s First Friday is Back To School themed. That's right, kids. Summer break is just about over, but the party in Downtown Bentonville this Friday ought to cheer you up!

  • Get schooled: To help ease the pain of heading back to school, vendors will be hosting back-to-school giveaways and games. Bentonville Schools will also be present with over 15 booths including fun crafts, science experiments, and more! 
  • The hostess with the mostess: Entertainment will include appearances by the Bentonville Schools Marching Band, School of Rock, Jenna & the Soul Shakers, and the Juice. But if you ask us, we're most excited for the Twinkie eating contest being put on by this month's sponsor, Hostess Brands.

See what to expect this Friday HERE.
node.name: First Friday

node.description:
The Walton Arts Center is fixing to lift the curtain for its 2022-23 P&G Broadway Series, and first on stage is a classic: My Fair Lady.

  • By George, she's got it: The original play by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe premiered on Broadway in 1956, won six Tony Awards, ran a record-breaking 2,717 performances, and was eventually followed by a film adaptation in 1964 starring Audrey Hepburn.
  • Don't miss it: There are eight showings scheduled between August 9-14. Ticket prices start at $41 and can be purchased in person, over the phone, or online.

Check out showtimes and get your tickets HERE.
node.name: My Fair Lady Kicks Off The Walton Arts Center Broadway Series

node.description:
The Momentary has more music in store for you this summer and fall, ranging from free concerts to multi-day events. 

  • Grab a blanket: Free concerts on the green will be on select Fridays starting this Friday, July 22, with the Manhattan Chamber Players String Sextet at 8p. Carm will perform on August 12 and Willi Carlisle on August 26. Stay tuned for more singer-songwriters, bands, and special guests. 
  • Teaser: Some ticketed performances and events include two-time Grammy-nominated indie pop artist Japanese Breakfast, the Tigran Hamasyan Trio, The War on Drugs kicking off FORMAT Festival, and a new festival experience - Momentous - with the full lineup of artists still to be announced. 

See the live music show lineup HERE.
node.name: Carm - Concerts on the Green

node.description:
It Came from Outer Space, a sci-fi musical about an astronomer who encounters a spaceship in the desert outside a small town, is on stage at TheatreSquared from Aug 24 - Sep 18. 

  • A cult-classic: Based on the 1953 cult-classic film, this musical adaptation by award-winning co-creators Joe Kinosian and Kellen Blair is sure to be an out-of-this-world experience. 
  • A can't miss: Tickets are priced from $20-$54 and can be purchased over the phone or online. There will be in-person shows and digital streaming options. 

Find show dates and purchase tickets HERE.
node.name: It Came From Outer Space at TheatreSquared

node.description:
Tis the season for summer series! In addition to starting a summer series tomorrow, Johnson is hosting its grand opening of Johnson Square.

  • The event: The Square is right next door to Hail Fellow Well Met at 5467 Hackett St., and live music by Nathan Perry and Smokey and the Mirror will start at 6p. The party will officially run until 8p, and there will be food and drinks too, so bring your friends!
  • The lineup: The summer series will continue on June 24 with a movie night, July 22 with Oh Jeremiah, August 26 with a movie night, and September 8 with The Riverside.

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Movie Night - Johnson Square Summer Series

node.description:
Open Avenues announced the 3rd annual SOAR NWA event will take place August 26-27 at the Drake Field in Fayetteville. 

  • Up and away: SOAR NWA is the region’s hot air balloon festival with various aeronautic activities for all ages. There will be a play zone for kiddos, a beer garden for those 21+, and activities like helicopter rides and discovery flights available for booking. 
  • Money well spent: The event is officially a fundraiser that enables Open Avenues to provide employment opportunities for people with disabilities. Both one and two-day ticket options are available, and tickets purchased in advance are $15 for adults and $5 for kids.

For tickets and more information, click HERE.
node.name: 3rd Annual SOAR NWA Dates Announced

node.description:
The Momentary has more music in store for you this summer and fall, ranging from free concerts to multi-day events. 

  • Grab a blanket: Free concerts on the green will be on select Fridays starting this Friday, July 22, with the Manhattan Chamber Players String Sextet at 8p. Carm will perform on August 12 and Willi Carlisle on August 26. Stay tuned for more singer-songwriters, bands, and special guests. 
  • Teaser: Some ticketed performances and events include two-time Grammy-nominated indie pop artist Japanese Breakfast, the Tigran Hamasyan Trio, The War on Drugs kicking off FORMAT Festival, and a new festival experience - Momentous - with the full lineup of artists still to be announced. 

See the live music show lineup HERE.
node.name: Willi Carlisle - Concerts on the Green

node.description:
This Thursday marks the last Thursday of August, and you know what that means — LIVE! @ Turnbow!

  • Movin’ & groovin’: LIVE! @ Turnbow is a free, outdoor event that features local musicians and bands — from jazz to mariachi, bluegrass, and funk. It all happens at Walter Turnbow Park in Downtown Springdale in the Outdoor Dining District, so you can grab a bite and a drink to enjoy while you vibe to the evening’s tunes. 
  • Lineup: This Thursday, music will be presented by The House of Songs and feature Duo Divinas, a Latinx singer-songwriter duo known for their Bachata-style music and cultural fusions, and The Irie Lions, an original 6-piece reggae band from Fayetteville. Music starts at 6:30!

Click HERE for more information.
node.name: LIVE! at Turnbow

node.description:
Embracing the energy of a changing season, the Momentary announced an exciting lineup of unique performance experiences through the end of the year.

  • Coming to you: A diverse lineup of artists will deliver genre-bending performances, from dynamic collaborations between Northwest Arkansas artists to international touring acrobatic theatre, as the contemporary art space continues to host artists engaging in thoughtful experimentation and play.
  • To choose from: Throughout the rest of 2022, guests can experience one-night collaborative performances, weekend experiences, week-long performances, and an entire art festival. From an all-woman acrobatic theatre to a contemporary chamber opera vocalist, composer, and more, there is much to see. So take your pick! Tickets are $0-$20, depending on the event. 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: When Visions Combine - Momentary

node.description:
Bentonville is about to get amped with the Amped Electric Games hosting its first-ever International Electric Unicycle Games early next month. 

  • One wheel: The Electric Unicycle Competition will be at the Bentonville Fairgrounds on the first weekend of September, and riders worldwide will be coming to compete. The events include on-road and off-road races, jump competitions, obstacle courses, and freestyle. 
  • Going Gold: Amped Electric Games is partnering with the American Childhood Cancer Organization during Childhood Cancer Awareness Month and donating event proceeds to the organization. The event will showcase the country's top electric unicycle riders, and you could even win an electric unicycle of your own! 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Electric Unicycle Games

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. Cincinnati - HOME

node.description:
Tis the season for summer series! In addition to starting a summer series tomorrow, Johnson is hosting its grand opening of Johnson Square.

  • The event: The Square is right next door to Hail Fellow Well Met at 5467 Hackett St., and live music by Nathan Perry and Smokey and the Mirror will start at 6p. The party will officially run until 8p, and there will be food and drinks too, so bring your friends!
  • The lineup: The summer series will continue on June 24 with a movie night, July 22 with Oh Jeremiah, August 26 with a movie night, and September 8 with The Riverside.

Learn more HERE.
node.name: The Riverside - Johnson Square Summer Series

node.description:
The Botanical Garden of the Ozarks' annual International Festival is one month out from today — September 18! 

  • All welcome: The International Festival is free for the public to attend and celebrates diversity, inclusion, and different cultures. The event will be on the last day of “Welcoming Week” (September 9-18), during which a series of events nationwide will bring people together and raise awareness of the benefits of inclusion. 
  • Learning and growth: The festival at the Botanical Garden of the Ozarks will feature food from around the world, traditional dance performances and demonstrations, arts, cultural items for sale, and more. Attendees will also have opportunity to talk to experts and engage with resources for multiple marginalized communities. 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Welcoming Week
node.location: Botanical Garden of the Ozarks - Fayetteville, AR

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. South Carolina - HOME

node.description:
The third annual Tour de Tacos is this Saturday, September 10, and online registration for the event closes today! 

  • Stops: Tour de Tacos will include 100, 62, 30, and 7-mile bike rides along the Razorback Greenway, with restaurants and businesses set up to provide cyclists food and hydration. The top-voted taco stop will receive the Cyclist Choice Award. 
  • Support: All rides will start and finish at KeyPoint Church in Bentonville and benefit women and families seeking economic independence through Dress for Success services. All proceeds from the event will go to them. Day-of-event registration will open at KeyPoint Church at 6a, so you last-minute folks can get in on the fun too! 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Tour de Tacos

node.description:
Embracing the energy of a changing season, the Momentary announced an exciting lineup of unique performance experiences through the end of the year.

  • Coming to you: A diverse lineup of artists will deliver genre-bending performances, from dynamic collaborations between Northwest Arkansas artists to international touring acrobatic theatre, as the contemporary art space continues to host artists engaging in thoughtful experimentation and play.
  • To choose from: Throughout the rest of 2022, guests can experience one-night collaborative performances, weekend experiences, week-long performances, and an entire art festival. From an all-woman acrobatic theatre to a contemporary chamber opera vocalist, composer, and more, there is much to see. So take your pick! Tickets are $0-$20, depending on the event. 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Bodies in the Land - Momentary

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. Missouri State - HOME

node.description:
Maria Fassi, a former golf star at the University of Arkansas and now an LPGA Tour professional launched a nonprofit called Fassi’s Friends a year ago and is hosting two events during the LPGA Tour in Northwest Arkansas to bring awareness to her growing foundation.

  • Events: Fassi’s Friends brings disabled and full-bodied kids together to learn golf for free. The second annual “Fassi’s Friends Topgolf Event” will take place on September 21, including food, drinks, and merch. There will also be a kids’ clinic at the First Tee in Lowell on September 22. 
  • Always a Razorback: Fassi played golf at the U of A from 2016-2019 and won 11 individual titles. She also became the first person to win the Annika award in back-to-back seasons.

Click HERE for more information.
node.name: Fassi’s Friends Topgolf Event

node.description:
Gaining national attention yesterday, Bentonville announced it will have its own Woodstock style festival this September.

  • The rundown: The new music, art, and technology event is called Format Festival, and will debut Sept. 23-25 on 250 acres of private land surrounding the Sugar Creek Airstrip in Bentonville. Tickets go on sale later this month.
  • Big vision: Inspired by Austin City Limits the event will have over 50 artist and it will be a mash up of music, visual art, and technology. C3 Presents will organize the festival who also does shows like Austin City Limits, Lollapalooza in Chicago and Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival.

Read more about the festival HERE.
node.name: FORMAT Festival

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. Texas A&M - AWAY

node.description:
The Best Friends Animal Society is hosting a dog friendly pub-crawl in Downtown Rogers this Saturday, Sept 24, from 3-7p. 

  • Best friends: Tickets for the Pup Crawl are good for one dog and one human and can be purchased online or at the Best Friends Animal Society tent any time during the event. All proceeds will support the state of the art Pet Resource Center set to open in Bentonville in early 2023.
  • A doggone deal: Pup crawlers will receive a stamp from participating bars and can redeem a stamped paws-port for 10% off purchases from participating businesses like Woof & Wander, Dandy Roll, The Urban Tub, Brick Lane Books, Threads 314, Nola's Pantry, The Shire Gastropub and more!

You can purchase tickets HERE.
node.name: Best Friends Animal Society Pup Crawl

node.description:
Bonnie Adams, the founder of Swim Oz, and Randy Wilburn sat down to have a conversation about open water swimming and the upcoming Walmart Oz Mile on I Am Northwest Arkansas.

  • Wide open water: Bonnie has been swimming since she was a young child, was a competitive D1 swimmer on the U of A swim team, and in addition to swimming competitively, she also owns and operates The Joys of Swimming teaching swimming lessons.
  • Bigger and better: 2021 marked the first year of the Oz Mile open water race on Beaver Lake, and it was a hit, drawing participants from around the state. Swimmers from across the US have already signed up for this year's Oz Mile being held on Sep 25.

Check out the episode with Bonnie on I Am Northwest Arkansas HERE.
node.name: Oz Mile Swim

node.description:
Embracing the energy of a changing season, the Momentary announced an exciting lineup of unique performance experiences through the end of the year.

  • Coming to you: A diverse lineup of artists will deliver genre-bending performances, from dynamic collaborations between Northwest Arkansas artists to international touring acrobatic theatre, as the contemporary art space continues to host artists engaging in thoughtful experimentation and play.
  • To choose from: Throughout the rest of 2022, guests can experience one-night collaborative performances, weekend experiences, week-long performances, and an entire art festival. From an all-woman acrobatic theatre to a contemporary chamber opera vocalist, composer, and more, there is much to see. So take your pick! Tickets are $0-$20, depending on the event. 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: All-female acrobatic theatre company Mimbre - Momentary

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. Alabama - HOME

node.description:
Presented by Tyson Foods, the Blessings Golf Club will host the third annual Blessings Collegiate Invitational this fall, Oct 3-5. 

  • Welcoming the best: Hosted by the Razorbacks, the event will feature top men’s and women’s teams from across the country including California, Central Florida, Clemson, Kansas, Louisville, Mississippi State, Texas A&M, UCLA, and others. 
  • Home course advantage: Last year, the Razorbacks captured all six tournament titles, and are ready to run it back! 

Stay up to date with event information and news HERE.
node.name: Blessings Collegiate Invitational

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. Mississippi State - AWAY

node.description:
Mark your calendars! The OZ CX Festival is set to feature the 2022 UCI Cyclo-cross World Cup the weekend of Oct 14-16. 

  • Global party: The event is expected to draw cyclists from more than 25 countries around the world, solidifying Arkansas’ reputation as an international destination for cycling sports. 
  • Local purpose: Featuring food trucks, music, and activities for guests of all ages, the festival will raise funds for Arkansas Children’s Northwest, highlighting the hospital's efforts to provide local access to specialized medical care for the children of NWA. 

Read the story from Arkansas Outside HERE
node.name: 2022 UCI Cyclo-Cross World Cup

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. BYU - AWAY

node.description:
Get ready to hear about all of the supply chain innovation, health & wellness startups, and adoption of Web3 at the Northwest Arkansas Technology Summit in October.

  • Huge in the Heartland: According to NWA Tech Summit's director, this conference is the biggest of its kind in the Heartland. In 2019, the last in-person version of the summit, 1,400 participants flocked to the conference. Even when it was held virtually, there were around 1,200 participants in both 2020 and 2021.
  • Show and tell: In its in-person format this year, participants will get to be fully immersed in great tech. Director, Kris Adams says "If you have something flashy and exciting and fun that you can show us...that's what we want to have at the Tech Summit this year."

If you're interested in attending, you can learn more and sign up HERE. You can also listen to The Bentonville Beacon's episode with Kris to learn more HERE.
node.name: NWA Tech Summit

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. Auburn - AWAY

node.description:
Downtown Springdale has announced its line-up of events for Ozarktober 2022! 

  • Celebrate: Ozarktober is a celebration of fall in the Ozarks and is held during October in downtown Springdale. This year, many events will take place outdoors and in the Outdoor Dining District from October 8-30. 
  • Fall fun: Events include live music and local brews, artist showcases, a multi-course brunch on a train, a haunted train, a bonfire, and more! Tickets for the events range from $0-$100 and are on sale now. 

Click HERE for more information.
node.name: Ozarktober 2022 - Oct 8 - 30

node.description:
Nightmare on Block Street is returning this year with events during the whole month of October! Primarily an immersive themed pop-up bar at Pinpoint in Fayetteville, there will be multiple events the public can enjoy around town.

  • Dress up: The Nightmare on Block Street pop-up bar will feature a new Halloween-themed menu and “a complete Halloween sensory overload.” The pinball machines at Pinpoint will be made scary, and it’s sure to be a good time. 
  • Get scary: Other events are Conjuring & Other Sins at 100 W Center, dubbed as “Fayetteville’s only truly haunted alleyway,” Bram Stoker’s Dracula presented by Ballet Arkansas, Horror Movie Screenings at Mt. Sequoyah, and a Vampire Blood drive at Pinpoint. 

Read the KNWA story HERE.
node.name: Nightmare on Block Street - Sep 30 - Nov 1

node.description:
Embracing the energy of a changing season, the Momentary announced an exciting lineup of unique performance experiences through the end of the year.

  • Coming to you: A diverse lineup of artists will deliver genre-bending performances, from dynamic collaborations between Northwest Arkansas artists to international touring acrobatic theatre, as the contemporary art space continues to host artists engaging in thoughtful experimentation and play.
  • To choose from: Throughout the rest of 2022, guests can experience one-night collaborative performances, weekend experiences, week-long performances, and an entire art festival. From an all-woman acrobatic theatre to a contemporary chamber opera vocalist, composer, and more, there is much to see. So take your pick! Tickets are $0-$20, depending on the event. 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Inverse - Momentary

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. Liberty - Home

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. LSU - Home

node.description:
Urban Land Institute is excited to announce the first NWA Place Summit, an event designed to educate, advocate, and partner with urban planning officials in the creation of quality places where people want to live, work, play, and learn.

  • The what: Hosted in downtown Bentonville on November 15-16, the event will feature dynamic speakers, interactive panel discussions, immersive tours, and informative workshops with national and regional leaders. 
  • The why: Summit participants will be challenged to consider how current and future built environments can aid in the continued effort to make NWA one of America’s greatest places. 

Stay up to date by signing up for ULI’s newsletter HERE.
node.name: NWA Place Summit

node.description:
Fayetteville will flip on the switch for the Lights of the Ozarks this Friday at 6p, sparking holiday magic across the Square and inspiring wannabe Clark Griswold’s across the city. 

  • Flip the switch: Lighting Night will also include a parade, a community carol led by the Symphony of Northwest Arkansas, free photos with Santa, and a huge selection of food trucks.
  • All season long: Enjoy holiday music, winter treats, hot cocoa, and plenty of vendors on the Downtown Square each night during Lights of the Ozarks until Jan 1. 

Vote Lights of the Ozarks as USA Today’s Best Public Holiday Lights Display HERE.
node.name: Fayetteville Lights The Square This Friday

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. Ole Miss - Home

node.description:
Americans and the Holocaust, a traveling exhibition from the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, will be on display at Mullins Library on the U of A campus until Dec 8. 

  • Observing the past: The exhibit examines America’s responses to Nazism, the war, and the genocide that took place in Europe during the 1930s and 1940s.
  • Interpreting the past: Taking visitors on a journey into the past, the memorial poses two primary questions: What did Americans know, and what more could have been done?

Learn more about the exhibit HERE.
node.name: U of A Hosts Traveling Exhibit From U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum

node.description: See Arkansas's full schedule HERE.
node.name: 🐗 Arkansas vs. Missouri - AWAY

node.description:
The Stewart Family Christmas Lights Display has been a community-favorite event for the holiday season since 2003, and it’s only gotten brighter through the years, now illuminating over 5m lights and hundreds of inflatables. 

  • Lights and more: Aside from the lights, enjoy a holiday train ride, take a ride on a pony or even a camel, and visit with the big man himself. That’s right, Santa will be there 7 days a week to hear all your holiday wishes. 
  • All season long: The display is located at 4279 Wyman Rd in Fayetteville, and will be open weekdays 5-10p and weekends 5-11p until Jan 3. Admission is $8. 

Find more information HERE.
node.name: Fayetteville’s Stewart Family Lights Display Is Open For The Season

node.description:
Bentonville's annual Christmas Parade will make its way through the streets of Downtown Bentonville this Saturday, Dec 10, starting at 6p. 

  • Float away: This year's parade includes over 100 floats and attractions, with more than 1,000 people participating in the festive march.  
  • Christmas lights: The parade's theme is "Colors of the Season" and will begin at the corner of 8th and Main St before winding around the Bentonville Square. 

Follow Downtown Bentonville Inc for updates HERE.
node.name: Bentonville's annual Christmas Parade

node.description:
The NWA Festival of Trees began Monday at Mount Sequoyah Center in Fayetteville, kicking off a two-week celebration in honor of the center's 100th year of providing programs on the mountain. 

  • Winter wonderland: Businesses, individuals, and community organizations can sponsor trees and wreaths to display during the event, with proceeds benefitting the restoration and preservation of the historic site. 
  • Let the fun begin: Festivities include caroling nights, pictures with Santa, the Wampus Wonderland Christmas Fair, and the Cheers to 100 Years Cocktail Party on Dec 10 from 5-7p. 

Find a full schedule of the event HERE.
node.name: NWA Festival of Trees

node.description:
Embracing the energy of a changing season, the Momentary announced an exciting lineup of unique performance experiences through the end of the year.

  • Coming to you: A diverse lineup of artists will deliver genre-bending performances, from dynamic collaborations between Northwest Arkansas artists to international touring acrobatic theatre, as the contemporary art space continues to host artists engaging in thoughtful experimentation and play.
  • To choose from: Throughout the rest of 2022, guests can experience one-night collaborative performances, weekend experiences, week-long performances, and an entire art festival. From an all-woman acrobatic theatre to a contemporary chamber opera vocalist, composer, and more, there is much to see. So take your pick! Tickets are $0-$20, depending on the event. 

Learn more HERE.
node.name: Imani Uzuri - Momentary

node.description:
Runners and walkers of all levels and ages are invited to participate in the 10th Annual Jingle Bell Jog 5K & Children’s Fun Run on Saturday, December 17th, 2022. Ugly Christmas sweaters, Santa hats, elf ears – anything that sparkles and jingles is highly encouraged! The first 200 children (12 and under) will receive a swag bag. Light snacks are included the morning of the race starting at 8:00 am. Come run, walk and be merry! No pets please.

All race finishers will receive a finisher medal. Awards will also be handed out to the fastest girl/woman and boy/man in each age group.

Proceeds support the Botanical Garden of the Ozarks’ mission to provide education, entertainment and recreation for the over 80,000 visitors and students who visit the garden each year.
node.name: Jingle Bell Jog

node.description:
The Rogers Short Film Festival, hosted by Arkansas Public Theater and StudioChunky, is scheduled for Mar 3-5 at the Victory Theater in Downtown Rogers.

  • Genres: Narrative, documentary, experimental, and animation film projects can be submitted in age and skill-specific categories. The submission deadline is Dec 23, with an extended submission deadline on Jan 23.
  • Upcoming: Official film selections will be released on Feb 3, and ticket sales will begin in mid-February, including options for Day Passes or VIP Passes.

Submit projects and stay informed HERE.
node.name: Rogers Short Film Festival

node.description:
Walton Arts Center will display 100 Photographs by Andrew Kilgore in the Joy Pratt Markham Gallery from Jan 6 - Mar 19, welcoming the public to enjoy a free exhibit of one of Arkansas's most distinguished photographers.

  • Worth 1,000 words: Since he opened a studio in Fayetteville in 1971, Andrew Kilgore has captured the dignity and diversity of Arkansans on film, intentionally highlighting some of the state's most marginalized groups.
  • Hear the stories: The exhibit will be open 10a-2p on weekdays from Jan 6 - Mar 19, with a free opening reception on Jan 6 from 5-7p and a public conversation with Kilgore on Feb 26 at 6p.

Learn more about the artist HERE.
node.name: 100 Photographs by Andrew Kilgore Opening Reception

node.description:
Ever imagine you'd see legendary snowboarder Shaun White throw a Double McTwist 1260... in front of a Walmart...in Arkansas? We didn't either, but there's a chance you might this Sunday, Jan 8, at the Pleasant Crossing Walmart in Rogers.

  • Stunts and snacks: Each time slot includes a showing of snowboarders performing epic stunts, athletes doing extreme trampoline flips, and a chance to sample Old El Paso's new Fiesta Twists.
  • Full 360º: Walmart+ Members can bring up to three guests, and the first 200 Walmart+ members have a chance to sign up for a meet and greet with Shaun White.

Learn more about the event and reserve a spot HERE.
node.name: Shaun White Visits Rogers For Fiesta Twists 360º Event

node.description:
The comedy-musical Tootsie is taking the stage at Walton Arts Center next week, providing eight chances to laugh your face off between Jan 17-22.

  • Tootsie role: This laugh-out-loud love letter to the theater tells the story of Michael Dorsey, a talented but difficult actor who struggles to find work until one show-stopping act of desperation lands him the role of a lifetime.
  • Rave reviews: Come experience this fresh new take on the 1982 film and see why it's being called a "musical comedy heaven" by Rolling Stone and "the most uproarious new musical in years!" by The Hollywood Reporter. 

Tickets start at $41. Get yours HERE.
node.name: Tootsie Takes The Stage Next Week At Walton Arts Center

node.description:
Ready for warmer weather so the kids can get out and play? Get ahead on your spring or summer plans by signing up for one of Peel Compton Foundation's outdoor learning experiences.

  • Natural learning: Coler Kids Camp immerses children, ages 8-12, in nature at Coler Preserve, keeping them active by learning outdoor skills. In the Explore Archery experience, teens ages 12-16 can receive archery training from certified instructors at The Quiver.
  • Adventure: Explore Osage is an exciting summer camp, providing children ages 8-12 with hands-on adventure by exploring the wetlands and learning archery at Osage Park.

Find more information and reserve spring or summer dates HERE.
node.name: Spring And Summer Camp Opportunities For Kids By Peel Compton Foundation

node.description:
What might be too early for your event calendar, but not ours is the Square 2 Square bike ride.

  • Fall in line: The Spring ride is scheduled for May 6 and the traffic will be moving north as riders ride from the Fayetteville Square to Bentonville Square.
  • The details: Online registration has officially opened and riders can sign up from now until May 3 for the 24-ish mile trek. With the event organizers offering shuttles, multiple rest stops, and on trail support, you've got plenty of time to get those legs spinning before May 6.

Read more about the event HERE.
node.name: Square to Square Spring Bike Ride
